A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
I 'get' the complaints and many of them are justified (there are at least 15 or so\, many of which are quite valid). Particularly I found the entire chase scene unbelievable. Worse than that was the constant exposition.
There is really no excuse for this\, Disney. Thirdly\, Finn is more or less a filler character. He added little in TFA and less in TLJ. Fourth\, I found the Jedi training to be even less believable than the star ship chase. However\, I think there are a few issues with the complaints of this film as well.

That being said\, I completely disagree that meta the story choices\, not plot points were poorly chosen. Luke was meant to die\, Leia was meant to live. Snoke was also a distraction from the story line\, a great character but highly problematic. All the meta choices were well thought through. The plot to get there was anything but\, it was "C-D" sci-fi flick rubbish.
You see the cultural and character development of backdrop of the story was great\, the races\, the casino\, the narrow chases\, the excellent sub plot characters and stories were all great. And honestly loved the humor\, it was fun and somewhat Oz esque. Likewise the conflict between Rey and Kylo was enough to be interesting.
What destroyed this movie from being great was the convoluted\, often ridiculous enough to unbelievable major plot points.
In Rian's defense\, I think he was handed a hot mess\, JJ Abram's made a much less interesting film. Super force users beating somewhat trained jedi\, and unceremoniously terrible execution of  of the most memorable character in the canon\, all at a hot and now pace.
Both movies suffer from a real lack of main character development that isn't spoonfed.
